{{other uses|Angel (disambiguation)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox film |name=The Angel |film name=''L'Ange'' |image=[[File:L'Ange film poster.jpg|200px|right]] |caption=Theatrical release poster |director=[[Patrick Bokanowski]] |writer=Patrick Bokanowski |producer=Patrick Bokanowski |music=[[Michèle Bokanowski]] |starring=[[Maurice Baquet]]
Jean-Marie Bon
Martine Couture
Jacques Faure
Mario Gonzales
René Patrignani
[[Rita Renoir]]
Patricia Peretti
Alain Salomon
Dominique Serrand
Nicolas Serreau
Max Guy Cravagnac
Abby Patrix |cinematography=Patrick Bokanowski |editing=Patrick Bokanowski |studio=Kira B.M. Films |distributor=Forum Distribution |released={{Film date|df=y|1982|05|25|[[International Critics' Week]]}} |runtime=64 Minutes |country=France |budget=[[French franc|F]] 3,200,000 }} '''''The Angel''''' ({{lang-fr|L'Ange}}) is a 1982{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924120739/http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/archives/ficheFilm/id/68eb986b-d031-4cf1-9340-aa9db77fa8ed/year/1982.html|url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/archives/ficheFilm/id/68eb986b-d031-4cf1-9340-aa9db77fa8ed/year/1982.html|title=''L'Ange''|accessdate=17 August 2015|work=[[Cannes Film Festival|Festival de Cannes (Archives: 1982, Selections)]]|archivedate=24 September 2015}} [[cinema of France|French]] [[silent film|silent]] [[experimental film|experimental]] [[art film]] directed by [[Patrick Bokanowski]]. It was released on [[DVD]] for the first time in 2009, edited by the British Animation Awards.{{cite web|url=http://www.britishanimationawards.com/dvd_shop/dvd_bokanowski01.htm|title=British Animation Awards: DVD Shop (Patrick Bokanowski: ''L'Ange'')|website=British Animation Awards|access-date=18 August 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://lightcone.org/en/filmmaker-27-patrick-bokanowski.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080405060157/http://www.lightcone.org/en/filmmaker-27-patrick-bokanowski.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=5 April 2008|title=Patrick Bokanowski|author=Pierre Coulibeuf|website=Light Cone: Distribution, Exhibition, and Conservation of Experimental Film (Filmmakers in Distribution)|access-date=18 August 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cjcinema.org/pages/fiche_auteur.php?auteur=26|title=Patrick Bokanowski|website=Collectif Jeune Cinéma: Parcourir auteurs|access-date=18 August 2015|language=fr}} The film was shown at [[Fantasporto]] during February [[1983 in film|1983]] and opened to the general public in [[France]] on 4 April [[1984 in film|1984]]. ==Synopsis== Given that the film is [[experimental film|experimental]], there is no proper narrative; rather, there is a guideline governing its development. The masked silhouettes climb stairs, and engage in various meetings on each level. This is a spiritual quest that doubles as a research on [[optical illusion]]s, Bokanowski recreating all the objectives of his cameras. This is a [[feature film]], which is rare for artisanal [[animation]] and [[experimental film|experimental]] films. In the booklet that accompanies the [[DVD]] which contains Bokanowski's sole two documentaries (''La Part du Hasard'', [[1984 in film|1984]], on the painter Henri Dimier; and ''Le Rêve éveillé'', [[2003 in film|2003]]; dialogues between the psychotherapist Colette Aboulker-Muscat and her patients), editor Pip Chodorov wrote: "The search for the overrunning of perception, and thereby oneself, is an expression of the spirituality present in the lives of these two figures: inspiration that we also found in Bokanowski's films, which are also searches into abstraction in the real, mysterious blanks that recover the daily. In his film ''The Angel'', characters search for light, and rise in spirals towards beacons of white and pure light, the librarian-researchers conduct a fierce intellectual quest, hoping for an illuminating response buried under mountains of books. Light plays a central role for the filmmaker, just like it does for the painter and therapist, as a peak of dramatic pleasure. We are pulled forward, upward, through these leaks in the twilight towards the light."Kira B.M. Films et Re:Voir Vidéo, [[2008 in film|2008]], p. 6. {{fr icon}} A CD album containing the soundtrack accompanying the film, composed by [[Michèle Bokanowski]], the director's wife, was released during 2003 by the label trAace under the title ''L'Ange''. ==Technical information== *Title: ''The Angel'' *Country: [[Cinema of France|France]] *Release Date: 25 May [[1982 in film|1982]] *Format: Color *Duration: 64 Minutes *Shooting: [[1977 in film|1977]]–[[1982 in film|1982]] *Directing, Editing, Special Effects, and Cinematography: [[Patrick Bokanowski]] *Music and Sound Editing: [[Michèle Bokanowski]] *Cameraman: Philippe Lavalette *Sets and Models: Christian Daninos and [[Patrick Bokanowski]] *Masks: Christian Daninos *Costumes: Domenika *Production: Kira B.M. Films *Distribution: Forum Distribution ===Cast=== *First Librarian: [[Maurice Baquet]] *Bathing Man: Jean-Marie Bon *Servant: Martine Couture *Swordsman/Handless Man: Jacques Faure *Librarian/Apprentice: Mario Gonzales *Librarian/Artist: René Patrignani *Naked Woman: [[Rita Renoir]] *Sewing Woman: Patricia Peretti *Librarian: Alain Salomon *Librarian: Dominique Serrand *Librarian: Nicolas Serreau *Librarian: Max Guy Cravagnac *Librarian: Abby Patrix ==Report on the animation== According to [[Raphaël Bassan]], in his article «''L'Ange'': Un météore dans le ciel de l'animation,» [[Patrick Bokanowski]]'s film, along with Piotr Kamler's film ''[[Chronopolis (film)|Chronopolis]]'', both having premiered in [[1982 in film|1982]] at the [[1982 Cannes Film Festival|Cannes Film Festival]], can be considered the beginnings of contemporary [[animation]]. This remark is based on the technical means and the visual or philosophical sense employed by [[Patrick Bokanowski]]. The masks erase all human personality in the characters. [[Patrick Bokanowski]] would thus have total control over the "matter" of the image and its optical composition. This is especially noticeable throughout the film, with images taken through distorted objectives or a plastic work on the sets and costumes, for example in the scene of the designer. ==The ascent towards light== Again according to [[Raphaël Bassan]], ''The Angel'' can be seen as a spiritual ascension. [[Patrick Bokanowski]] creates his own universe and obeys his own aesthetic logic. It takes us through a series of distorted areas, obscure visions, metamorphoses, and synthetic objects. Indeed, in the film, the human may be viewed as a fetish object (for example, the doll hanging by a thread), with reference to [[Franz Kafka#"Kafkaesque"|Kafkaesque]] and [[Sigmund Freud|Freudian]] theories on [[automaton|automata]] and the fear of man faced with something as complex as him. The ascent of the stairs would be the liberation of the ideas of death, culture, and sex that makes us reach the emblematic figure of the angel. ==Creating a plastic universe== For Jacques Kermabon, ''The Angel'' is a variation of [[optics]], as control and manipulation of light, as attested by the integration of plastic optical devices. Similarly, the effects on perspective diagrams emphasizes the relativity of this representation process. In the same gesture, the aesthetics of ''The Angel'', which opens up an infinity of possibilities, announces a cinema that would be before any movement, rhythm, rhyme, form, or work on the color and material: a cinema where the meaning is dissolved and effect predominates. In a way, [[Patrick Bokanowski]] brilliantly realized what some artists-filmmakers envisioned in the 1920s: an aesthetic for creations to come – the ''[[Cinéma pur]]'' and the [[French impressionist cinema|first avant-garde]]. ==References== ==Bibliography== *[[Raphaël Bassan]], «Bokanowski/Kamler: Deux avant-gardes graphiques,» ''Canal'', n° 49, juillet–septembre 1982. {{fr icon}} *[[Raphaël Bassan]], «''L'Ange'': Un météore dans le ciel de l'animation,» ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=HMYqAQAAIAAJ&dq=%22L%27Ange%3A+Un+m%C3%A9t%C3%A9ore+dans+le+ciel+de+l%27animation%22&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%22Un+m%C3%A9t%C3%A9ore+dans+le+ciel+de+l%27animation%22 La Revue du cinéma]'', n° 393, avril 1984. {{fr icon}} *Youssef Ishaghpour, «Bokanowski: ''L'Ange'',» ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=sXFZAAAAMAAJ&dq=Cin%C3%A9ma+contemporain%3A+De+ce+c%C3%B4t%C3%A9+du+miroir&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=bokanowski Cinéma contemporain: De ce côté du miroir]'', Paris, Éditions de la Différence, 1986, p. 318–331. {{fr icon}} *[[Patrick Bokanowski]], «''L'Ange'',» ''Noise n° 12'', Paris, [[Galerie Maeght|Maeght]] Éditeur, 1990. {{fr icon}} *Jacques Kermabon, «Portrait [[Patrick Bokanowski]],» ''Bref, le magazine du court métrage'', n° 20, février–mars–avril 1994, p. 17–19. {{fr icon}} *Scott MacDonald, "[[Patrick Bokanowski]] on ''The Angel''," ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=Dodrq_doxI4C&pg=PA262&lpg=PA262&dq=#v=onepage&q&f=false A Critical Cinema: Interviews with Independent Filmmakers 3]'', Oakland, [[University of California Press]], 1998, pp. 262–273. *[[Dominique Noguez]], ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=bF4bAQAAIAAJ&dq=editions:FA3jMqTETPwC Éloge du cinéma expérimental]'', Classiques de l'Avant-garde, Paris, Éditions Paris Expérimental, 2ème édition, 1999. {{fr icon}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|id=tt0083559|title=The Angel}} *{{Rotten Tomatoes|id=lange|title=The Angel}} *{{amg movie|74291|The Angel}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20160310102246/http://www.nytimes.com/movies/movie/74291/L-Ange/overview ''The Angel''] at ''[[The New York Times]]'' [https://www.nytimes.com/pages/movies/index.html Movies] *[http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/510784/Ange-L-/ ''The Angel''] at the [[Turner Classic Movies|TCM Movie Database]] *{{Discogs artist|12391-Michèle-Bokanowski|name=Michèle Bokanowski}} *{{IMDb name|id=nm1140873|name=Michèle Bokanowski}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Angel (1982 film), The}} [[Category:1980s avant-garde and experimental films]] [[Category:1980s business films]] [[Category:1980s drama films]] [[Category:1980s independent films]] [[Category:1982 films]] [[Category:Art films]] [[Category:Directorial debut films]] [[Category:Films about angels]] [[Category:Films about death]] [[Category:Films about disability]] [[Category:Films about education]] [[Category:Films about sexuality]] [[Category:Films about spirituality]] [[Category:Films about the arts]] [[Category:Films directed by Patrick Bokanowski]] [[Category:Films set in France]] [[Category:Films shot in France]] [[Category:French avant-garde and experimental films]] [[Category:French drama films]] [[Category:French films]] [[Category:French independent films]] [[Category:French silent feature films]] [[Category:Non-narrative films]] {{about|the current program|the unrelated radio and television series|The Goldbergs (broadcast series)}} {{Infobox television | show_name = The Goldbergs | image = The_Goldbergs_(2013)_Logo.png | caption = | show_name_2 = | genre = [[Sitcom]] | creator = [[Adam F. Goldberg]] | based_on = | developer = | writer = | director = | creative_director = | presenter = | starring = {{Plain list| * [[Wendi McLendon-Covey]] * [[Jeff Garlin]] * [[Sean Giambrone]] * [[Troy Gentile]] * [[Hayley Orrantia]] * [[George Segal]] * [[AJ Michalka]] * [[Sam Lerner]]}} | judges = | voices = | narrated = [[Patton Oswalt]] | theme_music_composer = [[I Fight Dragons]]{{cite web |url=http://www.ifightdragons.com/blog/?p=287 |title=Announcementsauce: We did the theme song for The Goldbergs on ABC! |publisher=Ifightdragons.com |date=September 30, 2013 |accessdate=January 29, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203182455/http://www.ifightdragons.com/blog/?p=287 |archivedate=February 3, 2014 |df= }} | opentheme = | endtheme = | composer = [[Michael Wandmacher]] | country = United States | language = English | num_seasons = 6 | num_episodes = 125 | list_episodes = List of The Goldbergs episodes | executive_producer = {{Plainlist| * [[Adam F. Goldberg]] * [[Doug Robinson (producer)|Doug Robinson]] * [[Allen Covert]] * [[Seth Gordon]] * Alex Barnow * Marc Firek * David Guarascio * [[Jack Giarraputo]] * [[Adam Sandler]] * David Katzenberg}} | producer = [[Dan Levy]] | location = [[Sony Pictures Studios]], [[Culver City, California]] | cinematography = Joseph E. Gallagher
Jason Blount | editor = Jonathan Corn
Ivan Victor
Peter B. Ellis
Kevin Leffler | camera = [[Single-camera setup|Single-camera]] | runtime = 22 minutes | company = {{Plainlist| * Adam F. Goldberg Productions * [[Happy Madison Productions]] * Doug Robinson Productions (2017-) * [[Sony Pictures Television]]}} | distributor = Sony Pictures Television | channel = [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] | picture_format = [[720p]] ([[16:9]] [[High-definition television|HDTV]]) | audio_format = [[5.1 surround sound]] with [[Descriptive Video Service]] on [[second audio program|SAP]] | first_run = | first_aired = {{Start date|2013|09|24}} | last_aired = present | related = ''[[Schooled (TV series)|Schooled]]'' | preceded_by = | followed_by = | website = http://beta.abc.go.com/shows/the-goldbergs | website_title = Official website | production_website = | alt = A family group photograph, all wearing jumpers with matching geometrical patterns. }} '''''The Goldbergs''''' is an American television [[Period piece|period]] [[sitcom]] that premiered on September 24, 2013, on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]. The series was created by [[Adam F. Goldberg]] and stars [[Wendi McLendon-Covey]], [[Jeff Garlin]], [[Sean Giambrone]], [[Troy Gentile]], [[Hayley Orrantia]], and [[George Segal]].{{cite web |url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2013/05/10/abc-renews-nashville-scandal-greys-anatomy-and-castle/ | title = ABC renews 'Nashville,' 'Scandal, 'Grey's Anatomy' and more | work = [[Entertainment Weekly]] | date = May 10, 2013 | accessdate = May 11, 2013 | author = Lynette Rice}} The show is produced by Adam F Goldberg, [[Seth Gordon]], and Doug Robinson.{{cite web |url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/devwatch/goldbergs/ | title = Goldbergs, The (ABC) | publisher = The Futon Critic | accessdate=May 11, 2013}} It is based on Goldberg's childhood and family in the 1980s, complete with a childhood version of himself. In May 2017, ABC renewed the series for a fifth and sixth season.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/05/the-goldbergs-renewed-season-5-6-abc-1202090214/|title='The Goldbergs’ Gets 2-Year Renewal By ABC For Seasons 5 & 6|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=May 11, 2017|accessdate=May 12, 2016}} The sixth season premiered on September 26, 2018.{{cite web |url=https://tvline.com/2018/07/24/abc-premiere-dates-fall-2018-greys-anatomy-the-conners/ |title=ABC Fall Premiere Dates: XL Grey's , Nathan Fillion's Rookie , The Conners (Minus Roseanne) and More |last=Swift |first=Andy |work=[[TVLine]] |date=July 24, 2018 |accessdate=July 24, 2018}} ==Premise== [[File:The Goldbergs 2013 logo.jpg|thumb|left|Promotional poster used for the series' first season]] ''The Goldbergs'' is set in the 1980s in [[Jenkintown, Pennsylvania]]. The show is loosely based on the showrunner's childhood, during which he videotaped events, many of which are reenacted throughout the program. It shows the reality of the 1980s through a young boy's eyes.{{cite web|url=http://www.jewishjournal.com/the_ticket/item/meet_the_goldbergs_adam_goldberg_mines_his_familys_mishegoss_for_new_sitcom|title=Meet ‘The Goldbergs’: Adam Goldberg mines his family’s mishegoss for new sitcom|last=Pfefferman|first=Naomi|work=Jewish Journal|publisher=TRIBE Media Corp|date=September 6, 2013|accessdate=May 1, 2014}} The series stars [[Jeff Garlin]] as patriarch Murray and [[Wendi McLendon-Covey]] as matriarch Beverly. Their two older children are Erica ([[Hayley Orrantia]]) and Barry ([[Troy Gentile]]). The youngest child, Adam ([[Sean Giambrone]]), documents his family life with his video camera. Beverly's father, Albert "Pops" Solomon ([[George Segal]]), is frequently around to provide advice or to help out his grandchildren (often behind his daughter's back). The present-day "Adult Adam" ([[Patton Oswalt]]) narrates every episode as taking place in "1980-something". Many references to real-life Philadelphia-area businesses are made, including the [[Wawa Inc.]] convenience store chain, [[Gimbel's]] department store, [[Willow Grove Park Mall]], and Kremp's Florist of [[Willow Grove, Pennsylvania]]. ==Cast and characters== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" ! scope="col" rowspan="2" | Character ! scope="col" rowspan="2" | Portrayed by ! scope="col" colspan="6" | Seasons |- ! scope="col" style="width:8%;" | [[The Goldbergs (season 1)|1]] ! scope="col" style="width:8%;" | [[The Goldbergs (season 2)|2]] ! scope="col" style="width:8%;" | [[The Goldbergs (season 3)|3]] ! scope="col" style="width:8%;" | [[The Goldbergs (season 4)|4]] ! scope="col" style="width:8%;" | [[The Goldbergs (season 5)|5]] ! scope="col" style="width:8%;" | [[The Goldbergs (season 6)|6]] |- |Beverly Goldberg (née Solomon) | [[Wendi McLendon-Covey]] | colspan=6 {{cMain}} |- |Adam Fredrick Goldberg |[[Sean Giambrone]] | colspan=6 {{cMain}} |- |Murray Christian Goldberg |[[Jeff Garlin]] | colspan=6 {{cMain}} |- |Barry Norman Goldberg |[[Troy Gentile]] | colspan=6 {{cMain}} |- |Erica Dorothy Goldberg |[[Hayley Orrantia]] | colspan=6 {{cMain}} |- |Albert "Pops" Solomon |[[George Segal]] | colspan=6 {{cMain}} |- |Lainey Lewis |[[AJ Michalka]] | colspan=2 {{cRecurring}} | colspan=2 {{cMain}} | colspan=1 {{cRecurring}} | colspan=2 {{cMain}} |- | Geoff 'Madman' Schwartz |[[Sam Lerner]] | colspan=1 {{n/a|}} | colspan=3 {{cRecurring}} | colspan=2 {{cMain}} |- | Erica "Valley Erica" Coolidge | Alison Rich | colspan=4 {{n/a|}} | colspan=1 {{cRecurring}} | colspan=1 {{cMain}} |} ===Main cast=== * [[Wendi McLendon-Covey]] as Beverly Goldberg (née Solomon), the overprotective matriarch of the Goldbergs. She is often called their "smother" by the kids. She frequently injects herself into her children's lives, often to their embarrassment, and is supremely confident in their abilities. * [[Sean Giambrone]] as [[Adam F. Goldberg|Adam Fredrick Goldberg]], the pop-culture obsessed youngest child of the Goldbergs. Smart and geeky, he often films his family's activities on a VHS camcorder. He often ends up having to use his middle initial to distinguish himself from another Adam Goldberg who attends the same school and is also an aspiring filmmaker. ** [[Patton Oswalt]] voices the adult Adam Goldberg,{{cite web|last=Lowry|first=Brian|title=TV Review: ''The Goldbergs''|url=https://variety.com/2013/tv/reviews/the-goldbergs-TV-review-1200613772/|work=Variety|date=September 17, 2013}} who narrates the show from the present day. * [[Jeff Garlin]] as Murray Goldberg, the gruff, somewhat asocial patriarch of the Goldbergs. Unlike Beverly, he is realistic about his children's abilities and believes she smothers them too much. Despite his apathetic tendencies at home, he values hard work and has held various full time positions since his teenage years. Though he does not always show affection for his children, calling them morons when they make mistakes or behave in silly ways, he truly cares about them and wants them to learn how to fend for themselves. He runs his father-in-law's furniture business, loves sports, and is often seen lounging in front of his TV in his white [[briefs]]. * [[Troy Gentile]] as Barry Norman Goldberg, the overconfident, slightly dim-witted middle child of the Goldbergs. Though seemingly untalented in every way (except in ice hockey and wrestling, at which he excels), he remains highly self-assured while trying to become popular in high school. He is determined to dominate everything he does, including sports; loves rap music; and is the leader of a crew called the Jenkintown Posse (abbreviated JTP, which fellow members repeat whenever the initials are spoken). In the fifth season finale, he proposes to Lainey and she accepts. By this point, he has also graduated. * [[Hayley Orrantia]] as Erica Dorothy Goldberg, the somewhat bad-tempered oldest child of the Goldbergs. Smart and musically gifted but rebellious, she is popular in school and dominant over her younger brothers. In the fifth season, Erica left for college at [[Duke Ellington School of the Arts|DC. School of the Arts]] only to drop out at the end of the season to start a band with Lainey and Valley Erica. "Erica" is based on Adam's real-life brother, Eric Goldberg.{{cite magazine |last=Wojciechowski |first=Michelle "Wojo" |date=May 17, 2016 |title=The Goldbergs Creator Adam F. Goldberg on Sharing His Family with the World |url=https://parade.com/477786/michelewojciechowski/the-goldbergs-creator-adam-f-goldberg-on-sharing-his-family-with-the-world/ |magazine=[[Parade (magazine)|Parade]] |access-date=April 18, 2018 |quote=He also made one other change—since it wasn’t supposed to be his family, he changed his oldest brother, Eric, to a girl, Erica.}} * [[George Segal]] as Albert "Pops" Solomon, Beverly's laid-back widower father. Though an elderly man with a number of comic eccentricities, he acts much younger than his age and often gives sage advice to his grandchildren. Adam considers him his best friend. He once owned a successful furniture store called Ottoman Empire that allowed him to retire comfortably, and he now lets his son-in-law Murray run the business. * [[AJ Michalka]] as Lainey Lewis (Season 3–4; recurring 1–2, 5–present),{{cite web|title=The Goldbergs - Season 5 - AJ Michalka Not Returning as Series Regular|url=http://www.spoilertv.com/2017/08/the-goldbergs-season-5-aj-michalka-not.html|website=SpoilerTV|publisher=SpoilerTV|accessdate=13 September 2017}} Erica's best friend and one of the most popular girls at school, whom Barry has had a lifelong crush on. To the surprise of many, Lainey kisses Barry at a party in the first-season finale, the two slowly grow closer together in season two, and eventually become an unlikely couple. Following the fourth season, she has gone to attend fashion school in Savannah, Georgia and ended her relationship with Barry. In season 5, she returns to Jenkintown after dropping out along with Erica to start a band. In the final seconds of the season finale she and Barry agree to wed. * [[Sam Lerner]] as 'Madman' Geoff Schwartz (Season 5–present; recurring 2–4),{{cite web|title=The Goldbergs - Season 5 - Sam Lerner promoted to regular|url=http://www.spoilertv.com/2017/08/the-goldbergs-season-5-sam-lerner.html|website=Spoiler TV|publisher=Spoiler TV|accessdate=13 September 2017}} one of Barry's best friends. The nickname "Madman" is a form of ironic humor, given how well-behaved the character is, especially compared to Barry. He is infatuated with Erica and makes many futile attempts to win her affections. At the end of the third season, he begins dating Evelyn Silver just as Erica realizes she reciprocates Geoff's feelings. He later breaks up with Evey to be with Erica. *Alison Rich as Erica "Valley Erica" Coolidge, Erica's [[Valley girl]] roommate at college; the two have the same first name, but decidedly different personalities. She dropped out of college with Erica and Lainey, and currently lives with the Goldbergs. (season 6; recurring 5) ===Recurring cast=== * [[Troy Winbush]] as Puchinski, a police officer who sometimes runs afoul of the Goldbergs' craziness, and often sympathises with Beverly. * [[Cedric Yarbrough]] as Vic, Murray's friend and co-worker from Canada. * Ben Zelevansky as Dale, the manager of the arcade frequented by Adam, Barry, and Pops. (season 1) * [[Natalie Alyn Lind]] as Dana Caldwell, Adam's classmate who becomes his girlfriend. In the season 2 finale, it is revealed Dana may be moving to Seattle. The season 3 premiere confirms she is now living in Seattle. Adam and Dana continue a long-distance relationship, but it ends when the two realize how different they have become. "Dana"'s real-life name is Amanda Caldwell; it was changed due to early legal concerns about the show's autobiographical quality.{{cite magazine |last=Goldberg |first=Lesley |date=April 22, 2014 |title='The Goldbergs' Boss Talks Time Slots, Plans for John Hughes, New Kids Tributes, More |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/goldbergs-boss-talks-time-slots-697442 |magazine=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |access-date= |quote=In the beginning, there were a lot of legal concerns about using real people. So Dana Caldwell is really Amanda Caldwell. Everyone had had concerns that it was so autobiographical. I changed her name, and then she Facebooked me and was happy and excited. That's my biggest regret: That I didn't use the real person's name.}} (season 1-3; guest season 4) * Jackson Odell as Ari Caldwell, a popular student, a friend of Erica and Lexi, and Dana's older brother. (season 1-2) * [[Virginia Gardner]] as Lexi Bloom, Barry's crush. (season 1, mentioned season 4) * [[Kathryn Leigh Scott]] as Miriam Ferguson, one of Pops' lovers. (season 1) * [[Jennifer Irwin]] as Virginia Kremp, Chad's mother, neighbor to the Goldbergs. * [[Jacob Hopkins]] as Chad Kremp, Virginia's youngest son and a close friend of Adam. * Tyler Stokes as Drew Kremp, Chad's older brother and Erica's ex-boyfriend. (season 1 and 3) * [[Dan Fogler]] as Marvin Goldberg, Murray's carefree, unreliable younger brother. He moves in with the family near the end of season four, living in their basement. * [[Tim Meadows]] as Jonathan "Andre" Glascott, a disenchanted teacher who also delivers pizza and gives guitar lessons for extra money. He serves as the school's hapless guidance counselor. * [[Barbara Alyn Woods]] as Mrs. Caldwell, Dana and Ari's mother. Woods is the real-life mother of Natalie Alyn Lind, who portrays Dana. (season 1) * Stephanie Katherine Grant as Emmy "Muscles" Mirsky, a girl in the neighborhood with whom Adam likes to spend time. Because they grew up together, she and Adam treat each other like siblings, and she behaves like "one of the guys" in the company of Adam and friends. * [[Kenny Ridwan]] as Dave Kim, an awkward classmate and friend of Adam's, who is always addressed by both his first and last names, even by his own mother. * [[Cooper Roth]] (season 1) and Zayne Emory (season 2-3) as [[J. C. Spink]], a bully who torments Adam. The original film producer who inspired the character portrays a school bus driver. * [[Mason Cook]] as Tyler Stansfield, a puny but fierce classmate of Adam. * [[Dustin Ybarra]] as Nitrous, a university student who occasionally interacts with Beverly. Usually Beverly has to make a demand of Nitrous, which he will agree to, but only after trying to coerce her into showing him her breasts or giving him $1 million. (season 1 and 3) * [[Bryan Callen]] as Rick Mellor, the high school's no-nonsense gym teacher and coach. * [[Joey Luthman]] as Roger McFadden, a nerdy classmate of Barry's. (season 1) * [[Stephen Tobolowsky]] as Principal Earl Ball, the principal of the Goldberg children's high school. Beverly frequently confronts him when she believes one of her children has been wronged during classes or school activities. (season 2-present) * [[Ana Gasteyer]] as Susan Cinoman, a music teacher at the Goldberg children's high school and love interest of Rick Mellor. (season 2-present) * [[Noah Munck]] as 'Naked' Rob Smith, one of Barry's best friends who goes shirtless at any opportunity. (season 2-present) * [[Matt Bush (actor)|Matt Bush]] as 'Ladies' Man' Andy Cogan, one of Barry's best friends who is frequently teased for his short stature. (season 2-present) * [[Nathan Gamble]] as Garry Ball, the Principal's rebellious son and Adam's only cool friend. (season 2-3) * [[Dan Bakkedahl]] as Mr. Woodburn, Adam's lonely and depressed science teacher. (season 2) * [[Suzy Nakamura]] as Mrs. Kim, Dave Kim's mother and the owner of a Chinese restaurant frequented by the Goldbergs. (season 2) * [[Rob Huebel]] as John Calabasas, an opportunistic businessman with several careers. (season 2-3, season 5) * [[Judd Hirsch]] as Ben "Pop Pop" Goldberg, Murray's cantankerous, opinionated father. He frequently fights with Murray, with whom he has trouble communicating, and he views Pops as a rival. (seasons 3-present; Pop Pop first appeared in one season 2 episode, and was portrayed by [[Paul Sorvino]]) * [[Allie Grant]] as Evelyn "Evey" Silver, a girl Beverly tries to set up Barry with. Erica is deeply disturbed by this, because Evey is eerily similar to Beverly. She later becomes Geoff Schwartz's girlfriend, albeit briefly. (season 2-present) * [[David Koechner]] as Bill Lewis, Lainey's father who is raising her as a single parent. To Murray's dismay, Bill is a major fan of the [[Dallas Cowboys]], starting a rivalry between the two. Bill and Murray eventually become good friends as they discover that, outside of football, they have a lot in common. (season 2-present) * [[Nate Hartley]] as Dan, a nerdy punching bag, who is always in the wrong place at the wrong time. (season 2-present) * Charlie DePew as Anthony Balsamo, a popular, good-looking student and Lainey's ex-boyfriend. (season 2-3) * Sam Kindseth as [[David Sirota]], Adam's goofy friend and classmate. In the present he is an American political commentator and radio host. (season 2-3, season 5) * [[Michaela Watkins]] as Ms. Taraborelli, a socially awkward Spanish and [[sex education]] teacher. (season 2) * Christopher Avila as Raji Mitra, an intelligent student Beverly hires to tutor Lainey. (season 3) * [[Sean Marquette]] as Johnny Atkins, a ponytailed, [[saxophone]]-playing troublemaker who, much like Barry Goldberg, has a high opinion of himself. He is always seen wearing a [[Rush (band)|Rush]] tour t-shirt. In addition to saxophone, he also plays the drums. Erica dated him briefly. (season 3-present) * Niko Guardado as [[Rubén Amaro, Jr.]], a highly popular student and champion athlete. Like Dave Kim, he is always addressed by his full name. In adulthood, he will become a major league baseball player and General Manager of Philadelphia Phillies. (season 3-present) * Alex Jennings as Carla Mann, a vaguely popular student and friend of Erica and Lainey who is a bit of a troublemaker. She is also an on-off girlfriend of Johnny Atkins. (season 3-present) * Froy Gutierrez as Benjamin "Handsome Ben" Bauman, a highly popular student whom Adam sees as his rival, though Ben is always friendly to him. * Quincy Fouse as Taz Money, a popular friend of Adam. (season 3) * Lucky: Lucky is an actual dog introduced in season 3 as the Goldberg family pet. * [[Shayne Topp]] as Matt Bradley; a punk rocker-turned-Deadhead who becomes the newest member of the JTP, over Barry's initial objections. Adult Adam's voice-over later confides that Matt would become Barry's closest friend after high school. (season 4-present) *[[Rowan Blanchard]] (seasons 4-5), Alexis G. Zall (season 6-present) as Jackie Geary, Adam's girlfriend who shares his love of science fiction.{{cite web|last1=Swift|first1=Andy|title=Rowan Blanchard Joins The Goldbergs in First Post-Girl Meets World Role|url=https://tvline.com/2017/02/06/rowan-blanchard-the-goldbergs-cast-girl-meets-world-star/|website=TVLine|accessdate=February 28, 2017|date=February 6, 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.spoilertv.com/2018/09/the-goldbergs-episode-602-you-got-zukod.html|title=The Goldbergs - Episode 6.02 - You Got Zuko'd - Press Release + Promotional Photos|website=SpoilerTV|first=Samantha|last=Benjamin|date=September 21, 2018|accessdate=September 23, 2018}} *Jackie Geary as Jackie's mother *JC Spink as Joe the Bus Driver *[[Ken Lerner]] as Lou Schwartz, Geoff's father. (season 5-present) *[[Mindy Sterling]] as Linda Schwartz, Geoff's mother. (season 5) *[[Brec Bassinger]] as Zoe McIntosh, a girl Adam had a crush on. (season 1, episode 1 and season 4, episode 3) *[[Bill Goldberg]] as Nick Mellor, Coach Mellor's brutish brother. (Season 5) ===Guest cast=== *[[Tom Cavanagh]] as Charles Kremp, Chad's father. (season 1, episode 8) *[[Martin Starr]] as Andre, the local video store clerk who bans Murray after an excessively late rental. (season 1) *[[Thomas Lennon]] as Taun-Taun Todd, a Star Wars fan that Erica and Adam meet while waiting in line to see ''[[Return of the Jedi]]''. (season 1, episode 22) *[[David Spade]] as Gus, a sketchy manufacturer of fake IDs. (season 2, episode 1) *[[Charlie Sheen]] as the man in the police station, reprising his iconic role from ''[[Ferris Bueller's Day Off]]''. (season 2, episode 14) *[[Nick Swardson]] as Rick, a sketchy black market toy dealer. (season 2, episode 15){{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/news/goldbergs-exclusive-nick-swardson-80s-toy/|title=Goldbergs Exclusive: What '80s Toy Is Beverly Trying to Buy From Nick Swardson?|author=Joyce Eng|date=28 January 2015|work=TVGuide.com}} *[[Chuck Norris]] as himself (voice only), who is heard from offscreen reading a letter to Barry. (season 3) *[[Weird Al Yankovic]] as himself. (season 3, episode 15) *[[Chad Coleman]] as Leon, a manager of Spencer's Gifts store. (season 4) *[[Martin Kove]] as Master John, reprising his role as [[The Karate Kid|Cobra Kai dojo sensei]]. (season 4) *[[Ilan Mitchell-Smith]] as Mr. Connelly, the science teacher in the fifth-season premiere episode "Weird Science." Mitchell-Smith portrayed Wyatt ''Donnelly'' in the film ''[[Weird Science (film)|Weird Science]]''. *[[Mike Quick]] as Coach Fast, an assistant football coach at William Penn. (Season 5) *[[Rick Moranis]] as Dark Helmet (voice only), reprising his role from the movie ''[[Spaceballs]]''. (Season 5) *[[Robert Englund]] as [[Freddy Krueger]], reprising his iconic role from ''[[A Nightmare on Elm Street]]''. (Season 6) ===Cameos from real-life counterparts=== *"Handsome" Ben Bauman and "Regular" Amy Gross as Double Dare Producers *Chad Kremp as a deli worker (season 1), and as his father (season 4) *[[R. D. Robb]] as a photographer *Michael C. Levy and Michael Z. Levy as Computer Technicians *[[Rubén Amaro Jr.]] as [[Rubén Amaro Sr.]] *Beverly Goldberg, Essie Karp, Virginia Kremp, and Linda Schwartz as a group of elderly friends that Beverly longs to be like *The real-life members of JTP (Barry Goldberg, Matt Bradley, Andy Cogan, Geoff Schwartz, and Rob Smith) all appear at the end of the episodes "Hail Barry" and "Colors" *Eric Goldberg (credited as "My Brother") at the end of "MTV Spring Break" *Emmy Mirsky (credited under her married name Emily McCoy) as Serry Mirsky, the Emmy character's mother in "Flashy Little Flashdancer" and "Hersheypark" ==Episodes== {{main|List of The Goldbergs episodes}} {{:List of The Goldbergs episodes}} ==Production== [[File:The Goldbergs cast 2014.jpg|thumb|right|From left to right: Segal, Gentile, McLendon-Covey, Orrantia, and Garlin]] ===Casting=== The project originally received a script commitment from [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] in August 2011. After Adam Goldberg's previous show, ''[[Breaking In (TV series)|Breaking In]]'', was canceled, he did not want to wait for another [[Television pilot#Pilot season|pilot season]] to arrive and moved it to ABC, who agreed to immediately produce it.{{cite web |url=http://www.deadline.com/2011/08/fox-to-bring-back-breaking-in-with-13-ep-order-buy-new-adam-goldberg-comedy/ | title=Fox To Bring Back 'Breaking In' With 13-Ep. Order, Buy New Adam Goldberg Comedy | website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] | date=August 24, 2011 | accessdate=May 11, 2013 | author=Nellie Andreeva}}{{cite web |url=http://www.deadline.com/2012/09/adam-f-goldbergs-comedy-moves-from-fox-to-abc-with-production-commitment/ | title=Adam F. Goldberg '80s Comedy Moves From Fox To ABC With Production Commitment | website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] | date=September 7, 2012 | accessdate=May 11, 2013 | author=Nellie Andreeva}} On January 11, 2013, [[Wendi McLendon-Covey]] was cast as the pilot's lead;{{cite web |url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/01/wendi-mclendon-covey-to-star-in-adam-goldbergs-1980s-comedy-pilot-at-abc/ | title=Wendi McLendon-Covey To Star In Adam Goldberg's 1980s Comedy Pilot At ABC | website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] | date=January 11, 2013 | accessdate=May 11, 2013 | author=Nellie Andreeva}} later, [[Jeff Garlin]] and [[George Segal]] joined the cast.{{cite web | url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/01/jeff-garlin-to-star-in-adam-goldberg%E2%80%99s-1980s-family-comedy-pilot-at-abc/ | title=Jeff Garlin To Star In Adam Goldberg's 1980s Family Comedy Pilot At ABC | website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] | date=January 28, 2013 | accessdate=May 11, 2013 | author=Nellie Andreeva | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Gjt6QRiT?url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/01/jeff-garlin-to-star-in-adam-goldberg%E2%80%99s-1980s-family-comedy-pilot-at-abc/ | archivedate=May 19, 2013 | df= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/02/maya-kazan-cast-in-cw-pilot-company-town-george-segal-in-abcs-how-the-hell/ | title=Maya Kazan Cast In CW Pilot 'Company Town', George Segal In ABC's 'How The Hell' | website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] | date=February 19, 2013 | accessdate=May 11, 2013 | author=Nellie Andreeva}} ===Filming=== The pilot episode was directed by [[Seth Gordon]]. On May 10, 2013, ABC picked up the show to series to air in the [[2013–14 United States network television schedule|2013–14 American television season]].{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2013/tv/news/abcs-first-new-series-order-goes-to-agents-of-shield-1200479556/ | title=ABC Orders 7 Dramas and 5 Comedies, Axes 'Happy Endings' | work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | accessdate=May 11, 2013 | author=Cynthia Littleton}} It was later picked up for a full season order on November 1, 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/abc-orders-full-seasons-goldbergs-652715 | title = ABC Orders Full Seasons of 'The Goldbergs,' 'Trophy Wife'; 'Super Fun Night' Gets 4 More Episodes |work = [[The Hollywood Reporter]] | date = November 1, 2013 | accessdate = November 1, 2013}} The program is filmed on a series of stages at [[Sony Pictures Studios]]. ===Music=== The show's theme song, "Rewind," was written at Goldberg's request by [[I Fight Dragons]], his favorite band, specifically for the show.{{cite web |url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/New-Show-Theme-Songs-1072874.aspx | title=How The Goldbergs and Other New Shows Kept Their Theme Songs | publisher=[[tvguide.com]] | date=November 1, 2013 | accessdate=November 9, 2013 | author=Michael Schneider}} A soundtrack, featuring songs performed on the show by the cast members, was released on December 6, 2017.{{cite web |url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/the-goldbergs-mixtape/1315844024?ls=1&app=itunes | title=The Goldbergs Mixtape by Various Artists | publisher=[[iTunes]] | accessdate=December 8, 2017}} ==Reception== ===Critical reception=== ''The Goldbergs'' first season received mixed reviews, averaging a score of 52% on [[Metacritic]] based on reviews from 26 critics.{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/the-goldbergs |title=The Goldbergs - Season 1 Reviews |publisher=Metacritic |accessdate=January 29, 2014}} Tim Goodman of ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' called it "one of the rare freshman comedies to deliver", giving credit to the show's "outstanding writing" and "strong cast".{{cite web|last=Goodman|first=Tim|title=The Goldbergs: TV Review|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/goldbergs-is-retro-funny-635017|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=September 24, 2013}} [[David Wiegand]] of the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' wrote, "you'll immediately like everyone in the family and the jokes derive from credible situations".{{cite web|last=Wiegand|first=David|title=Snarky 'Mom' seems hip, but 'Goldbergs' funnier|url=http://www.sfgate.com/tv/article/Snarky-Mom-seems-hip-but-Goldbergs-funnier-4834605.php|work=San Francisco Chronicle|date=September 22, 2013}} Hank Stuever of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' said the show was "obnoxiously loud".{{cite web|url=https://articles.washingtonpost.com/2013-09-23/entertainment/42326500_1_80s-the-goldbergs-patton-oswalt|title=‘The Goldbergs’: Back to the ’80s and totally gagging on ABC|work=The Washington Post| date=September 23, 2013|accessdate=September 27, 2013}} David Hinckley of ''[[Daily News (New York)|The New York Daily News]]'' said the show is "just awful".{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/goldbergs-trophy-wife-tv-reviews-article-1.1465164|title='The Goldbergs' and 'Trophy Wife': TV reviews|work=The New York Daily News|date=September 24, 2013|accessdate=September 27, 2013}} Tierney Bricker of ''[[E! News]]'' gave a more positive review, saying that the show is "like ''[[Modern Family]]'' mixed with ''[[A Christmas Story]]''".{{cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/462674/the-goldbergs-review-we-totally-want-to-be-a-part-of-abc-s-retro-family|title=The Goldbergs Review: We Totally Want to Be a Part of ABC's Retro Family|publisher=E! News|date=September 24, 2013|accessdate=September 27, 2013}} ''The Goldbergs'' was included in [[TV Guide]]{{'}}s 2013 Top Twenty "Best Shows of the Year",{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/special/best-of-year-2013/photogallery/Best-TV-Shows-2013-1074311 |title=The Goldbergs Pictures - Photo Gallery: The Best TV Shows of 2013 |publisher=Tvguide.com |date=2012-11-28 |accessdate=2014-05-10}} along with ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/bastard-machine/tim-goodmans-best-comedies-2013-665096 |title=Tim Goodman's Best Comedies of 2013 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date=2013-12-11 |accessdate=2014-05-10}} and ''[[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today]]''.{{cite web|author=Maggie Furlong |url=http://www.today.com/entertainment/11-breakout-hits-fall-tv-season-2D11783906 |title=11 breakout hits of the fall TV season - Entertainment |publisher=TODAY.com |date=2013-12-21 |accessdate=2014-05-10}} In addition, SpoilerTV awarded The Goldbergs with the honor of Best Comedy of 2013–2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.spoilertv.com/2014/05/last-week-in-tv-week-of-may-18-season.html|title=Last Week in TV - Week of May 18 - Season Awards and Reviews - Mega Version|work=SpoilerTV}} The second season had a [[Rotten Tomatoes]] score of 100% fresh with five reviews,{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/the-goldbergs/s02/|title=The Goldbergs: Season 2|date=24 September 2014|work=rottentomatoes.com}} and there were many calls from both critics and the public to renew the show for a third season.{{Citation needed|date=December 2016}} The show continued to be well received, with ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' calling the season two premiere "the best of any family comedy on TV in the way it eschews dysfunction for its more appropriate, real-world term: love".{{cite web|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2014/09/24/the-goldbergs-season-2-premiere/|title='The Goldbergs' season 2 premiere react: Same love, new mixtape|work=Entertainment Weekly's EW.com}} After the series was renewed for season 3, ABC network chief Paul Lee stated that both he and ABC believed that the show will be around for "a long time".{{cite web|url=http://renewcanceltv.com/the-goldbergs-season-4-abc-eyes-long-future/|title=The Goldbergs Season 4? ABC Eyes 'Long' Future - Renew Cancel TV|date=12 May 2015|publisher=|accessdate=2 March 2018}} ===Nielsen ratings=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; width:100%;" |- ! style="width:8%;" rowspan="2"| Season ! style="width:20%;" rowspan="2"| Timeslot ([[Eastern Time Zone (North America)|ET]]) ! style="width:8%;" rowspan="2"| # Ep. ! colspan=3| Premiered ! colspan=3| Ended ! style="width:10%;" rowspan="2"| TV Season ! style="width:10%; background:#ffdead;" rowspan="2"| Rank ! style="width:10%; background:#ffdead;" rowspan="2"| Viewers

! ! ! style="font-size:smaller"| [[2018–19 United States network television schedule|2018–2019]] ! style="background:#fc9;"| ! style="background:#fc9;"| ! style="background:#fc9;"| |- |} ==Broadcast== ''The Goldbergs'' originally premiered on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] on 24 September 2013.{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2014/07/15/abc-announces-fall-premiere-dates/283149/|title=ABC Announces Fall Premiere Dates|last=Kondolojy|first=Amanda|work=TV by the Numbers|date=July 15, 2014|accessdate=July 15, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150916221253/http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2014/07/15/abc-announces-fall-premiere-dates/283149/|archivedate=September 16, 2015|df=}} The pilot was made available on [[Hulu]] and ABC.com before it premiered on television.{{cite web | last = Spangler | first = Todd |url=https://variety.com/2013/digital/news/abc-teases-trio-of-fall-comedies-free-via-watch-abc-and-hulu-1200598656/ | title = Watch ABC Shows Free Online Fall Comedies | work = [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | accessdate = September 5, 2013}} In Australia, the show airs on the [[Seven Network]]. It has been broadcast in the United Kingdom on [[E4 (TV channel)|E4]] since 20 April 2015, in Ireland on [[RTÉ2]] since 19 October 2015 and in Turkey on DiziSmart since 2015. In France, the series began broadcasting since 17 October 2015 on Comedie+. The show has been broadcasting on [[Neox (TV channel)|Neox TV]] channel in [[Spain]] since {{Start date|2016|05|08}}. In India, the series is aired on [[Star World]]. In Germany, the series is aired on the [[Disney Channel (Germany)|Disney Channel]] since February 16, 2016.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sAyYUkPWqjo|title=DIE GOLDBERGS - Trailer - NEU im DISNEY CHANNEL|date=February 1, 2016}} In Portugal, the series is aired on Fox Comedy, while in Italy on Italia Uno, Mediaset. ==Syndication== The show went into syndication in September 2017 and began airing on local stations on September 11, [[Nick at Nite]] on September 18, and [[Pop (U.S. TV network)|Pop]] on September 24. ==Spin-off== {{Main|Schooled (TV series)}} In November 2016, it was first reported that ABC was developing a spin-off that would centre around recurring character Rick Mellor, played by Bryan Callen.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2016/11/08/development-update-tuesday-november-8-686012/11918/|title=Breaking News - Development Update: Tuesday, November 8 - TheFutonCritic.com|website=www.thefutoncritic.com|accessdate=2 March 2018}} On January 10, 2017, Wendi McClendon-Covey's character was reported as appearing in the script in a guest appearance.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2017/01/10/development-update-tuesday-january-10-201421/11970/|title=Breaking News - Development Update: Tuesday, January 10 - TheFutonCritic.com|website=www.thefutoncritic.com|accessdate=2 March 2018}} The script was ordered to pilot on February 2, 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2017/02/02/development-update-thursday-february-2-619121/11993/|title=Breaking News - Development Update: Thursday, February 2 - TheFutonCritic.com|website=www.thefutoncritic.com|accessdate=2 March 2018}} On March 16, 2017, it was confirmed that [[Nia Long]] had been cast as the female lead in the role of Lucy Winston. At the same time it was confirmed that [[Tim Meadows]] would reprise his recurring role from ''The Goldbergs'' as Andre Glascott. Jay Chandrasekhar was also confirmed to direct.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2017/03/09/development-update-thursday-march-9-66315/12027/|title=Breaking News - Development Update: Thursday, March 9 - TheFutonCritic.com|website=www.thefutoncritic.com|accessdate=2 March 2018}} On May 17, 2017, ABC passed on the spin-off,{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/adamfgoldberg/status/865011205139812352|title=Adam F. Goldberg Twitter|publisher=Adam F. Goldberg|date=May 17, 2017}} despite it reportedly testing very well - going as far to test better than the pilot of the original series.{{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/goldbergs-1990s-set-pilot-air-abc-1073142|title='The Goldbergs' 1990s-Set Pilot to Air on ABC|publisher=|accessdate=2 March 2018}} At the same time, Adam F. Goldberg revealed the title of the failed spin-off - "Schooled".{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/adamfgoldberg/status/865012519265460225|title=Adam F. Goldberg Twitter|publisher=Adam F. Goldberg|date=May 17, 2017}} On January 8, 2018, it was announced that the pilot would air as a special episode of ''The Goldbergs'' on January 24, 2018, under the episode title ''The Goldbergs: 1990-Something''. Along with Nia Long as Lucy Winston and Tim Meadows as teacher-turned-principal Andre Glascott (who is also revealed to be Lucy's brother), the pilot also starred [[Rachel Crow]] as Lucy's rebellious teenage daughter Felicia, and Summer Parker as Felicia's bubbly younger sister Gigi, with [[Octavia Spencer]] narrating as the present-day Felicia. After the pilot aired, Goldberg had expressed hope that the airing would prompt discussions with ABC that could lead to the series being picked up for the [[2018–19 United States network television schedule|2018–19]] TV season. Three months later, on April 16, 2018, it was announced that ABC had officially picked up the spin-off, ''Schooled'', for a 13-episode season slated to air in 2019. It was also announced that AJ Michalka would reprise her role as Lainey Lewis from ''The Goldbergs'' in the new show, but Nia Long will not return to the spin-off due to being a regular cast member on the [[CBS]] drama series ''[[NCIS: Los Angeles]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/goldbergs-1990s-set-spinoff-picked-up-series-at-abc-1090077|title='The Goldbergs' 1990s-Set Spinoff Picked Up to Series at ABC|website=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=April 16, 2018}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://beta.abc.go.com/shows/the-goldbergs}} * {{IMDb title|2712740|The Goldbergs}} * {{epguides|Goldbergs_2013}} * {{tv.com show|the-goldbergs-2013}} * {{TV Guide|556798}} {{The Goldbergs}} {{ABCNetwork Shows (current and upcoming)|state=collapsed}} {{Happy Madison Productions}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Goldbergs (TV series), The}} [[Category:The Goldbergs (2013 TV series)| ]] [[Category:2013 American television series debuts]] [[Category:2010s American single-camera sitcoms]] [[Category:American Broadcasting Company network shows]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of people]] [[Category:English-language television programs]] [[Category:Jenkintown, Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Jewish-related television programs]] [[Category:Television series about families]] [[Category:Television series about friendship]] [[Category:Television series about marriage]] [[Category:Television series about siblings]] [[Category:Television series by Happy Madison]] [[Category:Television series by Sony Pictures Television]] [[Category:Television series set in the 1980s]] [[Category:Television shows featuring audio description]] [[Category:Television shows set in Pennsylvania]]

{{infobox book | | name = The Informant | title_orig = | translator = | image = File:art9000widea.jpg | caption = | author = [[Kurt Eichenwald]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = [[Lysine price-fixing conspiracy]] | genre = | publisher = [[Random House]] ([[hardback]])
[[Broadway Books]] ([[paperback]]s) | pub_date = | release_date = [[2000]] | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover|Hardback]] & [[Paperback]]) | pages = 624 (hardback)
656 ([[Paperback#Trade paperback|trade paperback]] and [[movie tie-in]] edition) | isbn = 978-0-7679-0326-4 | dewey= 364.16/8/0973 1 | congress= HV8144.F43 E53 2000 | oclc= 44045679 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''The Informant''''' is a [[nonfiction]] [[white-collar crime]] book written by journalist [[Kurt Eichenwald]] and published in 2000 by [[Random House]].{{cite news |last=Webber |first=Susan |title=Tale of the Tapes |work=The Daily Deal |publisher=[[Aurora Advisors]], Inc. |date=2000-09-25 |url=http://www.auroraadvisors.com/articles/2000-09_dailydeal.html |accessdate=2008-10-02}} It documents the mid-1990s [[lysine price-fixing conspiracy]] case and the involvement of [[Archer Daniels Midland]] executive [[Mark Whitacre]], inspiring [[The Informant!|a film adaptation]] starring [[Matt Damon]] as Whitacre. ==Summary== {{see also|Lysine price-fixing conspiracy}} {{external media| float = right| video1 = [https://www.c-span.org/video/?160555-1/informant-true-story-part-1 Part One of ''Booknotes'' interview with Kurt Eichenwald on ''The Informant'', February 4, 2001], [[C-SPAN]]| video2 = [https://www.c-span.org/video/?160555-2/informant-true-story-part-2 Part Two of ''Booknotes'' interview, February 11, 2001], [[C-SPAN]]}} In the early 1990s, at the [[agri-business]] conglomerate [[Archer Daniels Midland]] (ADM), [[Mark Whitacre]] is a corporate vice president and head of the bio-products division. In November 1992, under pressure from his wife, Whitacre confesses to an [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] agent that he, along with other ADM executives, routinely met with competitors to fix the price of [[lysine]], a food additive. Afterwards, Whitacre assists in gathering evidence against the other conspirators by secretly taping their activities during overseas business meetings. Over the course of three years, the FBI collects hundreds of hours of video and audio tapes documenting the largest case of price-fixing in history. Whitacre is revealed to have defrauded $9 million from ADM at the same time he was aiding the FBI. After federal agents stage raid on ADM, the company hits back with damning evidence against the government's star witness. Whitacre becomes delusional and engages in [[pathological lying]] to save himself, leading the FBI to learn that he suffers from [[bipolar disorder]]. Worst of all, he gives false stories to the media about being forced to destroy evidence by the FBI. Whitacre becomes extremely manic, stops sleeping, and exhibits bizarre behavior as his meltdown continues. He attempts suicide a few months later, but is saved by his groundskeeper. After seeing the movie ''[[The Firm (1993 film)|The Firm]]'', Whitacre's delusional fantasy causes him to record and collect his conversations with FBI agents. Because he violated his immunity agreement with the government, Whitacre is charged with price-fixing along with the other ADM conspirators. Whitacre's attorney, James Epstein, successfully convinces the [[United States Department of Justice|Justice Department]] officials that the government was culpable for Whitacre's behavior as he was emotionally unprepared for the case. Epstein manages to get a very light sentence for Whitacre. However, Whitacre, unwilling to serve any jail time, fires Epstein. At his trial, Whitacre is convicted and receives a federal prison sentence three times longer than the other conspirators. Whitacre's FBI handlers, along with [[United States Attorney General|Attorney General]] [[John Ashcroft]], attempt to obtain a [[presidential pardon]] for Whitacre. With remarkable support from the FBI and his wife, Whitacre recovers from his mental problems and, after leaving prison, is promoted to COO and president of a California biotechnology company.{{cite news |author=Staff writers |title=Mark Whitacre, Ph.D. Promoted at Cypress Systems, Inc. and a Warner Bros. Movie to be Filmed About Him |work=News Blaze |date=2008-03-25 |url=http://newsblaze.com/story/2008032422530100001.sp/newsblaze/SENDPRES/Send2Press.html}}{{cite news |last=Ackerman |first=Ruthie |title=Whitacre’s Star Rises Again |work=Forbes |date=2008-03-27 |url=https://www.forbes.com/2008/03/25/whitacre-adm-cypress-face-markets-cx_ra_0325autofacescan03.html}} The guilty parties in the price-fixing conspiracy, including ADM, pay hundreds of millions of dollars in settlements and fines, while several ADM executives serve prison time. ==Film adaptation== {{Main|The Informant!}} The book was used as the basis for the movie ''The Informant!'', directed by [[Steven Soderbergh]] and starring [[Matt Damon]] as Mark Whitacre. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.randomhouse.com/features/informant/home.html The Informant — Kurt Eichenwald] — official [[Random House]] website *[http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/168/The-Fix-Is-In ''This American Life'' #168: The Fix Is In] (RealAudio) — interview with [[Mark Whitacre]] and the book's author, [[Kurt Eichenwald]], from ''[[This American Life]]'' {{DEFAULTSORT:Informant (Book)}} [[Category:2000 books]] [[Category:Agriculture books]] [[Category:Archer Daniels Midland]] [[Category:American non-fiction books]] [[Category:Books about bipolar disorder]] [[Category:Books about companies]] [[Category:Books adapted into films]] [[Category:Commercial crimes]] [[Category:Ethics books]] [[Category:Price fixing convictions]] [[Category:Random House books]]

page.title: The Tale of the Four Dervishes

revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''The Tale of the Four Dervishes''''' ({{lang-fa|قصه چهار درویش}} '''''Qissa-ye Chahār Darvēsh'''''; known in [[Urdu]] as '''''Bāgh-o Bahār''''' ({{Nastaliq|باغ و بہار}}, "Garden and Spring")) is a collection of allegorical stories by [[Amir Khusro]] written in [[Persian language|Persian]] in the early 13th century.
While legend says that Amir Khusro was the author, the tales were written long after his death. Legend has it that [[Amir Khusro]]'s master and [[Sufi]] saint [[Nizamuddin Auliya]] had fallen ill. To cheer him up, [[Amir Khusro]] started telling him a series of stories in the style of the ''[[One Thousand and One Nights]]''. By the end of the stories, [[Nizamuddin Auliya]] had recovered, and prayed that anyone who listened to these stories would also be cured.
==Style== The book is in some ways similar to the ''[[Thousand and One Nights]]'' in its method of framing and linking unfinished stories within each other. The central character is a king, Azad Bakht, who falls into depression after thinking about his own mortality, and so sets out from his palace seeking wise men. He comes upon four [[dervish]]es in a cemetery, and listens to their fantastical stories. Each Dervish narrates his own story, which is basically on love and fidelity in their own past lives. When the fourth dervish finishes his tale, the king Azadbakht suddenly learns that one of his wives has just born the son to him. Overwhelmed with joy, the king orders to arrange a great feast. With the help of the great king of jinns, Malik Syahpal, Azadbakht marries all the separated lovers to one another: the merchant’s son from Yemen to the princess of Damsyik, the prince of Fars to the princess of Basra, the prince of Ajam to the princess of Farang, the prince of Nimroz to the princess of jinns, and the prince of China to the daughter of the courtier, who was kidnapped by Malik Sadik. Everyone happily achieves the fulfilment of his or her desire
==Translations== These stories were originally written in [[Persian Language|Persian]] by [[Amir Khusro]] as ''Qissa-ye Chahār Darvēsh'' (''The Tale of the Four Dervishes''). It was initially translated by [[Mir Husain Ata Tehseen]] into [[Urdu language|Urdu]] as [[Nau Tarz-e-Murassa]] but the language was a highly literate one and was not understood by general public to enjoy. In 1801, [[College of Fort William]] in Calcutta started a project translating Indian literature. Mr. [[John Borthwick Gilchrist]], a famous scholar of literature, asked [[Mir Amman]], an employee of the college, to translate it into the [[Urdu]] language. Mir Amman translated it from [[Persian Language|Persian]] into everyday [[Urdu]], under the title ''Bāgh o Bahār'' (''The Garden and the Spring Season''). Later, in 1857, [[Duncan Forbes (linguist)|Duncan Forbes]] retranslated it into English. The translation of Mir Amman is still enjoyed as a classical work of [[Urdu Literature]] for the common daily language of its time.
== See also == * ''[[One Thousand and One Nights]]'' * [[Hamzanama]] * [[Persian Literature]]
==External links== * [http://www.columbia.edu/itc/mealac/pritchett/00urdu/baghobahar/intro_smith_forbes.html ''Bagh O Bahar'', or ''Tales of the Four Dervishes'' Online] * [https://archive.org/details/baghobaharortale12370gut ''Bagh O Bahar'' for download] * [http://www.mimrantaj.webs.com Ancient love stories]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Tale of the Four Dervishes}} [[Category:Sufi literature]] [[Category:Dervish]] [[Category:Chishti Order]] [[Category:Pakistani folklore]] [[Category:Persian literature]] [[Category:Persian fairy tales]] [[Category:Urdu-language literature]]

page.title: The Temptation of St Anthony (Bosch painting)

{{For|the triptych painting by the same artist|Triptych of the Temptation of St. Anthony}} {{Infobox Artwork | image_file = The Temptation of St Anthony (Bosch).jpg | title = The Temptation of St. Anthony | artist = Hieronymus Bosch, or follower | year = c. 1500–1525 | type = Oil on panel | height_metric = 73 <!--prev. "70" unverified; contradicts MdP--> | width_metric = 52.5 <!--prev. "51" unverified; contradicts MdP--> | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | dimensions_ref = <ref name="Museodelprado" /> | museum = Museo del Prado, Madrid}}
'''''The Temptation of St. Anthony''''' is a painting of disputed authorship, attributed to either [[Hieronymus Bosch]] or a follower. It is currently housed in the [[Museo del Prado]] in Madrid.
==History== The work was in the [[El Escorial|Escorial]] monastery, although it was not mentioned in inventories; later it was moved to the Prado. It is likely that the work was one of the ''Temptations'' sent to the monastery by [[Philip II of Spain]] in 1574. This painting has a more serene atmosphere than the [[triptych]] with the same theme now in the [[National Museum of Ancient Art|Museu Nacional de Arte Antiga]] of [[Lisbon]].<ref name="Varallo">{{cite book |first=Franca |last=Varallo |title=Bosch |publisher=Skira |location=Milan |year=2004}}</ref>
Like all Bosch's works, it cannot be dated with precision, although it is likely from his late production (1500–1516).<ref name="Varallo"/>
In 2016, the Bosch Research and Conservation project, after five years of researching all known Bosch paintings, announced that they had significant doubts about the attribution of the work to Bosch, instead attributing it to a follower.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/17/arts/design/prado-museum-rescinds-loan-of-downgraded-hieronymus-bosch-works.html|title = Prado Museum Rescinds Loan of Downgraded Hieronymus Bosch Works|last = Siegal|first = Nina|date = 2016-02-16|newspaper = The New York Times|issn = 0362-4331|access-date = 2016-03-12}}</ref>
==Description== [[File:J. Bosch Prado Temptation of St Anthony (detail).jpg|thumb|240px|left|Detail]] [[Anthony the Great|St. Anthony the Abbot]] is portrayed in meditation, in a sunny landscape near the trunk of a dry tree. St. Anthony is a recurrent figure in Bosch's work, with up to 15 paintings of this subject, all inspired by legends told in the ''[[Golden Legend]]'' and in his ''Life'' by [[Athanasius of Alexandria]]. He is represented in a setting of solitude and temptation that the saint experienced over twenty years. Although this picture is significantly different from other works by Bosch of St. Anthony, such as the triptych painting of the same name, customary features of the abbot include his dark brown habit with the Greek letter "[[tau]]" and a pig by his side.<ref name="Museodelprado">{{cite web |title=The Temptation of Saint Anthony |accessdate=2015-06-14 |publisher=Museo Nacional del Prado |location=Madrid, Spain |url=https://www.museodelprado.es/en/the-collection/online-gallery/on-line-gallery/obra/the-temptation-of-saint-anthony/}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Kren |first1=Emil |last2=Marx |first2=Daniel |url=http://www.wga.hu/html/b/bosch/5panels/07anthon.html |title=The Temptation of St Anthony |website=The Web Gallery of Art |accessdate=26 February 2010}}</ref>
In contrast to the earlier paintings with St. Anthony, this version of the temptation of St. Anthony finds the abbot calmer from his meditative spirit. His surroundings are peaceful and evoke a sense of calm. The pig lies next to him like a pet. Once demons, the creatures of temptation are now more like goblins and do not disturb the peaceful feeling of the painting.
This painting, originally framed with a semi-circular arch, was one of Bosch's later works, from sometime after 1490. [[Philip II of Spain]] sent it to the Monastery of El Escorial near Madrid. From there the painting came to the Museo del Prado as part of the Royal Collection.<ref name="Museodelprado" />
==See also== *''[[Triptych of the Temptation of St. Anthony]]'' *[[List of paintings by Hieronymus Bosch]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Sources== *{{cite book|first=Franca |last=Varallo |title=Bosch |publisher=Skira |location=Milan |year=2004 |isbn=978-88-572-0615-8}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2017}} {{Infobox award | name = UK Music Video Awards | current_awards = 2018 UK Music Video Awards | description = excellence in music video and moving image for music | country = United Kingdom | year = 2008 | website = [http://www.ukmva.com/ www.ukmva.com] }} The '''UK Music Video Awards''' is an annual celebration of [[creativity]], technical excellence and [[innovation]] in [[music video]] and moving image for music. The awards began in 2008. There is a wide range of opportunities for [[United Kingdom|UK]] individuals and companies to enter their work: from genre-led video categories, to prizes for individuals in the technical and craft areas of the business, to recognition for innovative approaches to music videos, [[Advertising|ads]] and other visuals.{{Cite news |url=http://www.musicweek.com/media/read/bowie-beyonce-and-radiohead-among-uk-music-video-awards-nominees/066022 |title=UK Music Video Awards returns; entries now open |date=June 28, 2016 |work=Music Week}} There are also awards for international videos and outstanding individuals, voted for by the MVA jury members.{{Cite news |url=http://www.nme.com/news/music/foals-99-1247060 |title=Foals, Florence + The Machine, James Blake nominated for UK Music Video Awards |date=October 13, 2013 |work=NME}} The Awards take place in the autumn, with the entry process opening in early August. The UK MVA’s are organised by two of the key members of the team behind BUG, the [[BFI Southbank]]’s music video strand, and have 20 years’ experience running events in the UK music video business. ==2008== The 2008 UK Music Video Awards, hosted by [[Adam Buxton]], took place at the Odeon West End, Leicester Square, London on October 14th.{{cite web|url=https://www.promonews.tv/news/2008/10/14/uk-music-video-awards-2008-all-winners/1466 |title=UK Music Video Awards 2008 - all the winners! |publisher=Promonews |date=14 Oct 2008}}{{cite web|url=https://www.ukmva.com/Pages/Detail/84-2008 |title=UKMVA Past Winners 2008 |website=www.ukmva.com |access-date=14 Nov 2018}} {| class="wikitable" |- !Video of the Year !Best Pop Video !Best Rock Video |- |'''[[Björk]] — "[[Wanderlust (Björk song)|Wanderlust]]"'''
